Line 51: Line 51:  
This definition means that 'love' in Buddhism refers to something quite different from the ordinary term of love which is usually about attachment, more or less successful relationships and sex; all of which rarely occur without self-interest. Instead, in Buddhism it refers to de-tachment and the unselfish interest in others' welfare.
 
This definition means that 'love' in Buddhism refers to something quite different from the ordinary term of love which is usually about attachment, more or less successful relationships and sex; all of which rarely occur without self-interest. Instead, in Buddhism it refers to de-tachment and the unselfish interest in others' welfare.
    −
[[Hindu]] writers, theologians and philosophers have distinguished nine forms of devotion that they call bhakti e.g. in the [[Bhagavatha-Purana]] and according to [[Tulsidas]]. The booklet ''Narada bhakti sutra'' written by an unknown author distinguishes eleven forms. Not all Hindu [[sect]]s consider bhakti important.
+
[[Hindu]] writers, theologians and philosophers have distinguished nine forms of devotion that they call [[bhakti]] e.g. in the [[Bhagavatha-Purana]] and according to [[Tulsidas]]. The booklet ''Narada bhakti sutra'' written by an unknown author distinguishes eleven forms. Not all Hindu [[sect]]s consider bhakti important.
     
Different cultures have deified love, typically in both male and female form. Here is a list of the gods and goddesses of love in different mythologies.
